questions.text: A 45-year-old fisherman presents with a painful wound infection following an injury sustained while handling seafood. Upon evaluation, a Gram-negative, salt-tolerant bacterium is identified. Which of the following organisms is not classified as a non-fermenting bacterium?

A 55-year-old patient with chronic gastritis undergoes diagnostic testing for Helicobacter pylori infection. The tests include both invasive and non-invasive methods. Which of the following non-invasive tests is specifically known for its ability to detect active H. pylori infection and provide rapid results?
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Genetic Features
  • Significant genetic diversity
  • Key genes: cag (cytotoxin-associated gene), vac (vacuolating cytotoxin gene)
  • Urease production and motility contribute to pathogenesis

Clinical Manifestations
  • Asymptomatic colonization to severe gastric diseases
  • Potential outcomes: peptic ulcer disease, chronic atrophic gastritis, gastric adenocarcinoma, MALT lymphomas
  • MALT lymphomas often regress with eradication

Immune Response
  • Involves IgM, IgG, IgA production
  • Cellular immunity activation
  • Immune response does not effectively protect against infection

Invasive Diagnostic Tests
  • Endoscopic Biopsy: Tissue sample from gastric mucosa
  • Rapid Urease Test: Detects urease; results in minutes
  • Microscopy: Identifies H. pylori with staining
  • Culture: Most sensitive; involves growing bacteria; results in 3-7 days

Non-Invasive Diagnostic Tests
  • Serology (ELISA): Detects antibodies; useful for epidemiology, less reliable for active infection
  • Urea Breath Test: Detects active infection by measuring carbon dioxide from carbon-labeled urea breakdown; sensitive and reliable

Treatment
  • Standard: Bismuth subsalicylate + two antibiotics (tetracycline or amoxicillin + metronidazole) for two weeks
  • Alternative: Proton pump inhibitor (e.g., omeprazole) + clarithromycin
  • Treatment recommended for H. pylori-associated gastric or duodenal ulcers
  • Challenges: Antibiotic resistance, high recurrence rate

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with severe, watery diarrhea resembling "rice-water stools" and signs of dehydration. Laboratory tests confirm a Vibrio cholerae infection. Which of the following best explains the mechanism by which cholera toxin induces watery diarrhea?

options.label: A
options.text: Causes direct intestinal mucosal damage, leading to inflammation and diarrhea

options.label: B
options.text: Activates adenylate cyclase, resulting in increased cyclic AMP levels

options.label: C
options.text: Increases cyclic GMP levels in intestinal cells

options.label: D
options.text: B subunit binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Activates adenylate cyclase, resulting in increased cyclic AMP levels

questions.text: What is the preferred diagnostic test for confirming a case of leptospirosis?
Gram stain of a painful genital ulcer exudate shows gram-negative coccobacilli in a "school of fish" arrangement. Which statement about the suspected pathogen is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Requires X factor but not V factor; grows on vancomycin-supplemented chocolate agar

options.label: B
options.text: "Pushing test" is diagnostic; further laboratory confirmation unnecessary

options.label: C
options.text: Multiplex PCR is less sensitive than culture for diagnosis

options.label: D
options.text: Single-dose azithromycin; partner treatment optional if asymptomatic

questions.correct_answer: A. Requires X factor but not V factor; grows on vancomycin-supplemented chocolate agar

questions.text: A 6-month-old unvaccinated infant presents with paroxysmal cough followed by whooping inspiration and post-tussive vomiting for the past 2 weeks. Which of the following is the most sensitive and specific method for confirming the diagnosis in this case?

options.label: C
options.text: Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) of nasopharyngeal aspirate

options.label: D
options.text: Serological testing for anti-pertussis toxin IgG

questions.correct_answer: C. Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) of nasopharyngeal aspirate

questions.text: A 35-year-old veterinarian presents with intermittent fever, sweating, and joint pain. Blood cultures are performed, but the initial results are negative. Further laboratory tests show a significant titer of 640 in the Standard Agglutination Test (SAT). Which of the following characteristics is least likely associated with the causative organism?

options.label: D
options.text: Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes

questions.explanation:
Morphology

Biochemical Properties

Growth & Susceptibility

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli (Option A ruled out)

Catalase positive

Do not grow well on standard laboratory media

Non-capsulated and non-spore forming

Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis)

Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes (Option D ruled out)

Often exhibit a bipolar staining appearance

Urease positive (Option B ruled out)

Killed by 1% phenol in 15 minutes
 

Utilize oxygen but do not typically ferment carbohydrates

Killed by pasteurization

Test

Description

Key Points

Standard Agglutination Test (SAT)

Tube agglutination test using serial dilutions of patient's serum and killed B. abortus antigen
  • Significant titer: 160 or more.
  • Acute brucellosis titer: 640 or more within 3-4 weeks.
  • Prozone phenomenon common.
  • False positives with cholera, tularemia, yersinia infection, or immunization

Complement Fixation Test

Detects IgG antibodies
  • Valuable in chronic cases

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)

Distinguishes between IgM and IgG antibodies
  • Useful for differentiating acute from chronic infections

Rapid Tests

Includes rapid dipstick tests and Rose Bengal card test
  • Quick results.
  • Can be used for initial screening

Characteristic

Details

Morphology

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli, Non-capsulated, non-spore forming, Bipolar staining

Biochemical Properties

Catalase positive, Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis), Urease positive, Utilize oxygen, do not ferment carbohydrates

Growth & Susceptibility
  • Do not grow well on standard media.
  • Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 min, Killed by 1% phenol in 15 min, Killed by pasteurization.

Zoonotic Nature

Affects goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, pigs. Human infection through contact or consumption.

Symptoms

Intermittent fever, loss of appetite, nausea, muscular and articular pains, fatigue, sweating, joint pain.

Blood Culture
  • Trypticase soy broth or brucella broth. Biphasic blood culture (Castaneda method).
  • Large blood volume (5 ml). Incubation: 37°C, 5-10% CO2, 6-8 weeks. 30-50% positive cases. Bone marrow cultureshave a higher yield.

Serological Tests

SAT: Significant titer 160+, Acute 640+, Complement Fixation: IgG detection, ELISA: Distinguishes IgM & IgG. Rapid Tests: Dipstick, Rose Bengal

Antibiotics

Adults: Doxycycline 45 days, Streptomycin 2 weeks, Children: Cotrimoxazole + Rifampicin/Gentamycin.

Vaccination

No human vaccine, Occupational risk: Attenuated live vaccine, Animals: B. abortus strain 19 vaccine.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Stool cultures reveal the presence of a gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that is oxidase-negative, ferments glucose, and reduces nitrate to nitrite. Which of the following bacteria is most likely the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Tribe

Genus

Escherichiae

Escherichia (Option A), Shigella

Edwardsiellae

Edwardsiella

Salmonellae

Salmonella

Citrobacteriaceae

Citrobacter

Klebsielleae

Klebsiella, Enterobacter, Serratia, Hafnia, Pantoea

Proteae

Proteus, Providencia, Morganella

Yersinieae

Yersinia

Erwinieae

Erwinia

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is suspected to have a urinary tract infection. After culturing her urine sample on MacConkey agar, pink colonies of E. coli are isolated. Which component in the agar is responsible for changing the color to pink?
questions.explanation:
Lactose Fermenters
  • Escherichia coli
  • Klebsiella
  • Enterobacter
  • Citrobacter

Late Lactose Fermenters
  • Shigella sonnei

Non-Lactose Fermenters
  • Salmonella
  • Shigella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia

Test

Indicator

Lactose Fermenters

Non-Lactose Fermenters

MacConkey Agar

Neutral Red (Option B)

Pink or red colonies

Colorless colonies

Eosin Methylene Blue Agar (EMB)

Eosin Y and Methylene Blue (Option D ruled out)

Dark purple to black, or with a green metallic sheen

Colorless or light pink

Cystine Lactose Electrolyte-Deficient (CLED)

Bromothymol Blue (Option A ruled out)

Color change from green to yellow

-

questions.text: Which combination of biochemical tests is best suited for confirming the identification of Escherichia coli in a clinical laboratory?

options.label: A
options.text: Indole Test, Methyl Red (MR) Test, Voges-Proskauer (VP) Test, and Citrate Utilization Test

options.label: B
options.text: Gram Staining, Urease Test, Catalase Test, and Oxidase Test

options.label: C
options.text: Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) Agar, Urease Test, Citrate Utilization Test, and Methyl Red (MR) Test

options.label: D
options.text: Indole Test, Urease Test, Voges-Proskauer (VP) Test, and Oxidase Test

questions.correct_answer: A. Indole Test, Methyl Red (MR) Test, Voges-Proskauer (VP) Test, and Citrate Utilization Test
questions.explanation:
Test

Result

Indole Production

E. coli is typically indole positive.

Methyl Red (MR) Test

E. coli shows a positive result.

Voges-Proskauer (VP) Test

E. coli is typically negative.

Citrate Utilization

E. coli usually does not utilize citrate (negative result).

Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) Agar

Shows fermentation of glucose, lactose, and production of gas.

Urease Test

E. coli is urease negative.

questions.text: Which toxin produced by Shigella inhibits protein synthesis in host cells and has the potential to cause hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)?
questions.explanation:
Type of Toxin

Produced By

Mechanism

Effects

Shiga Toxin (Stx)

Shigella dysenteriae type 1

Inhibits protein synthesis in host cells by cleaving a specific adenine residue from the 28S rRNA of the 60S ribosomal subunit.

Causes cell death, contributes to intestinal damage, and can lead to hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) in severe cases.

Enterotoxins (ShET-1 & ShET-2) (Option A ruled out)

Various Shigella species

Induce fluid secretion in the intestine, contributing to diarrhea.

Promote diarrhea by causing fluid accumulation in the intestinal lumen.

Ipa Proteins (Option C ruled out)

-

Facilitate entry into host epithelial cells and escape from phagosomes.

Enhance bacterial invasion and survival within host cells.

IcsA (VirG) (Option D ruled out)

-

Promotes actin polymerization for intracellular movement and spread to adjacent cells.

Aids in the spread of Shigella within the intestinal epithelium.

Injected by Type III Secretion System (T3SS)

-

Proteins like IpaB, IpaC, and IpaD disrupt host cell processes, aiding in bacterial invasion and evasion of the host immune response.

Enhance bacterial survival and replication by evading host immune defenses.

Endotoxins

-

Due to the lipopolysaccharides (LPS) of the Gram-negative cell wall.

Contributes to inflammatory response and symptoms associated with infection.

questions.text: Match the following Klebsiella species with the diseases they commonly cause: 1. Klebsiella pneumoniae A. Granuloma inguinale 2. Klebsiella oxytoca B. Pneumonia 3. Klebsiella granulomatis C. Rhinoscleroma 4. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis D. Hemorrhagic colitis
questions.explanation:
Klebsiella Species

Disease Caused

Symptoms

Klebsiella pneumoniae

Pneumonia

Productive cough with "currant jelly" sputum, fever, chills, chest pain, difficulty breathing

 

Klebsiella oxytoca

Hemorrhagic colitis

Bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and cramping, nausea, vomiting

Klebsiella granulomatis

Granuloma inguinale

Painless, beefy-red genital or anal ulcers, tissue granulation, bleeding from lesions

Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

Rhinoscleroma

Nasal congestion, nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, crusting, swelling, tissue thickening, deformity

questions.text: In a microbiological study, two different strains of Proteus are inoculated at separate points on the same agar plate containing a non-inhibitory medium. Upon observation, the areas of growth from each strain remain distinctly separate with a line of demarcation between them. What phenomenon is being demonstrated in this experiment?

A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high fever, chills, and a painful swelling in his axillary region. He reports that he recently returned from a trip to Himachal Pradesh. On physical examination, a large, tender lymph node is noted in the axillary region. Aspirate when stained with methylene blue is shown in the image below. Which of the following organisms does not show a similar typical appearance as seen in the image?
questions.explanation:
Plague (Yersinia pestis)

Endemic Foci
  • Kolar (Tamil Nadu),
  • Beed Latur (Maharashtra)
  • Rhoru (Himachal)

Reservoir

Wild rodents

Vector

Rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis, Xenopsylla astia)

Types of Plague
  • Bubonic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; Lymph node painful enlargement and fever
  • Pneumonic Plague: 1-3 days incubation period; Respiratory symptoms; Associated with bio-terrorism
  • Septicemic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; A/k/a Black death; DIC, shock and multi-organ failure

Microscopic Findings

Safety pin appearance (Bipolar staining) using Wayson stain, Wright stain, Giemsa stain

Culture
  • Nutrient broth with oil/ghee (Ghee broth): Stalactite growth (hanging from the top)
  • Selective CIN agar: Bullseye colonies

 

Biochemical Reactions
  • Fermentation [+ve acid production -ve gas production]
  • Catalase positive
  • Oxidase negative
  • IMViC = - - + -

Vaccine

  • Recombinant R1F1v Vaccine: Pre-exposure Prophylaxis
  • Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine- Protects only against bubonic plague,

Treatment

  • Streptomycin
  • Fluoroquinolones: For CNS and cardiovascular involvement

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a 7-day history of high-grade fever, chills, and generalized weakness. The fever has been persistent and gradually increasing in intensity, reaching 39.5°C (103.1°F) and, often rising in the afternoon and evening. The patient also reports abdominal pain and has experienced several episodes of diarrhea, characterized by intermittent loose, greenish stools which started a few days after the onset of fever. On examination, pulse is 60/min, and BP is 110/70 mmHg. He appears ill with a coated tongue and mild hepatosplenomegaly. Based on the clinical scenario above, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
